title: How to lodge a complaint at Trident?
short_description: Confused about where to complain and how to actually get things fixed? Hereâ€™s your all-in-one Trident guide to solving problems without the chaos.
long_description:
Dearest Tridents,

It has come to this authorâ€™s attention that while our hostel is a vibrant palace of friendship, festivity, and last-minute deadlines, it is occasionally interrupted by the great villains of student life: leaking taps, flickering tube lights, mysteriously jammed doors, and the ever-controversial mess food mishaps.

And in such moments of distress, one must know not just whom to blame, but where to complain. Fear not, for this guide promises to transform even the most bewildered resident into a confident connoisseur of complaint-lodging.

If your troubles lie in the realm of maintenanceâ€”creaking beds, faulty switches, or taps that behave like fountainsâ€”your first stop is the venerable Complaint Book at the Hall Managerâ€™s office.

For electrical, plumbing, or carpentry issues, the kingdom offers a modern weapon: support.iitb.ac.in. A few clicks and your grievance is officially in the system.

Should your concerns be about the messâ€”undercooked, overcooked, or questionably cookedâ€” and if the Mess Manager is available, report the issue immediately, document it in the Feedback Register, attach a photo, and collect a signature. Then proceed to the Mess Council or Warden.

If the Mess Manager is not present, report to the serving counter staff, register the complaint with photographic proof, and obtain their signature before escalating the matter.

If no one acknowledges your plea, approach the Hall Manager. Record the refusal in the Feedback Register, secure a signature, gather your proof, and present your case to the Mess Council or Warden.

May this guide be your torch in the labyrinth of repairs, signatures, and grievances.
â€”Your Ever-Observant Chronicler

title: Diwali Celebrations at Trident
short_description: A sparkling recap of the three-day Diwali weekend at Trident â€” from mehendi and movies to board games, rangoli, karaoke, and a serene Laxmi Pooja.
long_description:
Dearest Residents of Hostel Trident,

Diwali, the festival of lights, has once again cast its golden glow upon our beloved home. And as always, Trident proved that when it comes to celebration, we settle for nothing short of brilliance. With diyas glowing, fairy lights twinkling, and joy humming gently through every corridor, our hostel transformed into a sight that could leave even the stars themselves a little envious.

Allow me now to recount what unfolded over this most enchanting three-day Diwali weekend.

The festivities commenced on Saturday, with a Mehendi & Movie Night that turned the lounge room into a dreamy haven. Soft fairy lights draped the walls, mattresses lined the floor, and mehendi cones passed from hand to hand as girls adorned each other with intricate designs. And what better cinematic companion than the evergreen charm of Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge? Laughter echoed, dancing erupted whenever Raj and Simran graced the screen, and bowls of popcorn made their way through the crowd like treasured offerings.

Sunday arrived with equal enthusiasm, bringing with it a lively Board Games & Rangoli Night.A cozy corner of the mess shone under warm lights as Monopoly, Ludo, Shaasan, and Bollywood-themed playing cards awaited their next champions. Meanwhile, a beautiful rangoli began taking shape â€” petal by petal, colour by colour â€” as talented hands worked their magic. Soon enough, the night transformed into an impromptu karaoke gathering: voices rising with confidence, speakers booming with favourite songs, and the mic passed around like a crown of temporary stardom.

Finally, on Monday â€” the day of Diwali itself â€” the celebrations found their peaceful crescendo with a serene Laxmi Pooja in the mess. Surrounded by light, devotion, and quiet warmth,the ritual blessed our hostel with prosperity and togetherness that lingered long after the final diya dimmed.

Thus, dear readers, concluded Tridentâ€™s radiant Diwali weekend: three days of colour, music, laughter, devotion, and memoriesthat shall no doubt live fondly in the hearts of all who witnessed them.

Yours in festive admiration,
The Observer of All Things Delightfully Trident

title: Dahi Handi Redefined
short_description: A midnight Janmashtami twist you never expected â€” Tridentâ€™s girls reinvented Dahi Handi in the most delightful way. Curious how it unfolded? Start reading!
long_description:
Dearest Tridents,

It seems the ever-spirited residents of Hostel 15 have once again proven that tradition, when placed in their hands, transforms into something far more enchanting. As the clock struck midnight on Janmashtami, long before the campus slipped fully into slumber, an unusual excitement began brewing in our mess.

This year, our clever young ladies decided that the age-old tradition of climbing human pyramids for Dahi Handi deserved a Trident-style makeoverâ€”one that was far less bruising and far more entertaining. And thus, a new chapter of festivities was born.

A modest earthen pot was tied just high enough to stretch for, not scramble toward. But do not be fooled by its gentle heightâ€”chaos still found its way. Pairs of girls stepped forward, one blindfolded and armed with a stick, the other entrusted with guiding her companion only through words. No touching, no nudgingâ€”just trust, instinct, and occasionally, wildly miscalculated directions.

The crowd swelled quickly, cheers echoing through the midnight air as each duo attempted their heroic (and often hilarious) journey. At one point, dear reader, a particularly determined participant swung with such passion that the stick snappedâ€”a tragic end for the pot, but a triumphant moment for laughter.

Yet beneath all the fun, a familiar truth shimmered gently: happiness often arrives disguised as shared giggles, festive madness, and the simple joy of being surrounded by glowing faces. And if festivals serve one purpose, it is thisâ€” to coax out the happiness we sometimes forget we carry.

Until the next celebration,
â€”Your Ever-Observant Chronicler
